FieldValue.Value: Geriatrics: percentage of female patients aged 65 years and older with a diagnosis of urinary incontinence whose urinary incontinence was characterized at least once within 12 months.

American Geriatrics Society (AGS), American Medical Association (AMA)-convened Physician Consortium for Performance Improvement® (PCPI), National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA). Geriatrics: performance measurement set. Washington (DC): National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA); 2013 Jul. 40 p. [11 references]
Clinical Quality Measures: Process
Does not apply to this measure

This measure is used to assess the percentage of female patients aged 65 years and older with a diagnosis of urinary incontinence whose urinary incontinence was characterized at least once within 12 months.

Treatment indications are dependent on the severity and impact on the patient.

The following clinical recommendation statements are quoted verbatim from the referenced clinical guidelines and represent the evidence base for the measure:

Patients with urinary incontinence (UI) should undergo a basic evaluation that includes a history, physical examination, measurement of postvoid residual volume, and urinalysis (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists [ACOG], 2005).

Health care providers should be able to initiate evaluation and treatment of UI basing their judgment on the results of history, physical examination, postvoiding residual and urinalysis (Fonda et al., 2005).

Bladder diaries provide valuable information on severity and bladder capacity in older persons without disability in the community (Fonda et al., 2005).
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Urinary incontinence in women. Obstet Gynecol. 2005 Jun;105(6):1533-45. PubMed

American Geriatrics Society (AGS), American Medical Association (AMA)-convened Physician Consortium for Performance Improvement® (PCPI), National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA). Geriatrics: performance measurement set. Washington (DC): National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA); 2013 Jul. 40 p. [11 references]

Fonda D, DuBeau CE, Harari D et al. Incontinence in the frail elderly. In: Abrams P, Cardazo L, Khoury S, Wein A, editor(s). Incontinence: 3rd International Consultation on Incontinence (ICI). Plymouth (England): Health Publication, Ltd.; 2005.
Geriatrics; characterization of urinary incontinence
All female patients aged 65 years and older with a diagnosis of urinary incontinence (see the related "Denominator Inclusions/Exclusions" field)
Patients whose urinary incontinence was characterized at least once within 12 months (see the related "Numerator Inclusions/Exclusions" field)

not defined yet

Inclusions
Patients whose urinary incontinence was characterized at least once within 12 months

Note:

  • Characterization of urinary incontinence may include one or more of the following: frequency, volume, timing, type of symptoms, and how bothersome to the patient.
  • Refer to the original measure documentation for administrative codes.
